verses.text: When you sit down to eat with a ruler, pay careful attention to what is before you,
verses.comment: Wisdom teaches self-control in the presence of the powerful. The context reflects ancient Near Eastern customs of feasting, which often involved subtle politics.

verses.text: and put a knife to your throat if you are a person given to hunger.
verses.comment: The phrase is metaphorical, stressing the importance of restraint. In Jewish wisdom, self-mastery is central (see Sirach 31:12–18 for similar thought).

verses.text: Do not desire his delicacies, for they are deceptive food.
verses.comment: The warning here is about the danger of coveting luxury—ties to themes of temptation seen throughout Wisdom literature.

verses.text: Do not toil to gain riches; cease from your own understanding.
verses.comment: Real security comes not from worldly wealth but from trust beyond our own perception—echoes trust in divine providence.

verses.text: When your eyes glance at riches, they are gone; for they surely sprout wings, flying like an eagle toward heaven.
verses.comment: Riches are fleeting, an important reminder about spiritual rather than material treasures. New Testament echoes are found in Matthew 6:19-21.

verses.text: Do not eat the bread of a selfish man, nor desire his delicacies;
verses.comment: The selfish person is not generous in spirit; his gifts are not truly given. Hospitality is seen as a sign of virtue in biblical tradition.

verses.text: for as he calculates within himself, so he is. 'Eat and drink,' he says to you, but his heart is not with you.
verses.comment: What a person truly thinks matters more than surface speech. The interior disposition is key—a foreshadowing of Christ’s emphasis on inward purity (Matthew 15:18).

verses.text: You will vomit up the morsels you have eaten and lose your pleasant words.
verses.comment: False generosity leads to regret. What is not sincerely given or received is spiritually empty.

verses.text: Do not speak in the hearing of a fool, for he will despise the wisdom of your words.
verses.comment: Wisdom distinguishes between receptive and unreceptive listeners. Christ Himself often spoke in parables to conceal truth from the hard-hearted (Matthew 13:13-15).

verses.text: Do not remove the ancient boundary stone, nor enter the fields of the fatherless;
verses.comment: Respect for ancestral property upholds justice and charity, key virtues in the biblical tradition. Protecting the vulnerable resonates with the New Testament concern for widows and orphans (James 1:27).

verses.text: for their Defender is strong; He will plead their case against you.
verses.comment: God champions the weak—a foreshadowing of Christ’s deep love for the poor and marginalized. Therein lies a call for social justice rooted in divine order.

verses.text: Apply your heart to instruction and your ears to words of knowledge.
verses.comment: The spiritual life requires discipline and receptivity to teaching. The 'heart' and 'ears' are traditional symbols of interior conversion.

verses.text: Do not withhold discipline from a child; if you punish him with the rod, he will not die.
verses.comment: Proper discipline is vital for genuine formation. This verse emphasizes correction as loving guidance, not harshness.

verses.text: You shall punish him with the rod and save his soul from Sheol.
verses.comment: Discipline has a salvific purpose—turning from destructive paths protects one's soul from death. Salvation themes echo Christ’s redeeming work (Luke 15:7).

verses.text: My son, if your heart is wise, my heart will rejoice, even mine.
verses.comment: Spiritual parenthood reflects divine Fatherhood; wisdom brings communal joy and unity.

verses.text: Yes, my innermost being will rejoice when your lips speak what is right.
verses.comment: Truth spoken with wisdom reflects the transformation of the soul. Christ calls us to speak and live by the truth (John 8:32).

verses.text: Do not let your heart envy sinners, but be in reverent fear of the LORD all day long.
verses.comment: Holy fear, not envy, marks the path of wisdom. This continual reverence prefigures the call to constant prayer (1 Thessalonians 5:17).

verses.text: Certainly there is a future, and your hope will not be cut off.
verses.comment: Hope in God's providence looks beyond temporary hardship to eternal promise.

verses.text: Listen, my son, and be wise, and guide your heart in the way.
verses.comment: Guidance is both intellectual and spiritual—'the way' foreshadows Christ’s description of Himself as the way (John 14:6).

verses.text: Do not be with those who drink too much wine or gorge themselves on meat;
verses.comment: Moderation in all things is wisdom. Temperance, a key virtue, underpins both physical and spiritual health.

verses.text: for the drunkard and glutton will come to poverty, and drowsiness will clothe one in rags.
verses.comment: Vice leads to ruin. The wisdom tradition connects physical habits with spiritual consequences.

verses.text: Listen to your father who gave you life, and do not despise your mother when she is old.
verses.comment: Honor towards parents is foundational; it is repeated in both Old and New Testaments (Ephesians 6:1-2). Here, the continuity of tradition in family is valued.

verses.text: Buy the truth and do not sell it—wisdom, instruction, and understanding.
verses.comment: Truth is priceless. The pursuit of wisdom echoes the search for the pearl of great price (Matthew 13:46).

verses.text: The father of a righteous child will greatly rejoice; he who bears a wise child will be glad because of him.
verses.comment: Parental joy in children's virtue reflects the generational blessing of faithfulness.

verses.text: Let your father and your mother be glad; let her who bore you rejoice.
verses.comment: The wisdom tradition puts high value on honoring the family, hinting at the virtue of honoring those who came before us—a theme seen in the veneration of saints.

verses.text: My son, give me your heart, and let your eyes delight in my ways.
verses.comment: A calling to total surrender of heart foreshadows deepest forms of spiritual communion.

verses.text: For a prostitute is a deep pit, and an adulteress is a narrow well;
verses.comment: Sexual sin is portrayed as deadly—a motif echoed by Christ’s warnings about impurity (Matthew 5:28).

verses.text: she lurks like a robber and increases the number of the faithless among men.
verses.comment: Faithlessness in personal morality often leads to faithlessness in spiritual matters. The fidelity of heart found in the biblical witness is urged here.

verses.text: Who has woe? Who has sorrow? Who has strife? Who has complaining? Who has wounds without cause? Who has red eyes?
verses.comment: This rhetorical question points toward the consequences of intemperance and sin. Christ’s call to joy and peace contrasts the woe of sin.

verses.text: Those who linger over wine, who go to taste mixed wine.
verses.comment: Substance abuse leads to ruin—a practical wisdom for health of body and soul.

verses.text: Do not look at wine when it is red, when it sparkles in the cup, when it smoothly goes down.
verses.comment: The seduction of sin is often sensory—proverbs warn against the lure of fleeting pleasure.

verses.text: In the end it bites like a serpent and stings like a viper.
verses.comment: Sin’s pleasurable beginning hides destructive consequences. The serpent image recalls Genesis 3:1-14 and the cycle of temptation and fall.

verses.text: Your eyes will see strange things, and your heart will utter perverse words.
verses.comment: Intoxication distorts perception and corrupts speech, pointing to the dangers of all moral compromise.

verses.text: You will be like one who lies down in the midst of the sea, like one who lies on top of a mast.
verses.comment: The image of instability powerfully conveys the spiritual danger in yielding to vice.

verses.text: 'They struck me,' you will say, 'but I was not hurt; they beat me, but I did not feel it. When will I wake up so I can find another drink?'
verses.comment: Addiction's cycle is here exposed. True freedom comes not by indulgence but by grace, a theme Christ brings to fulfillment (John 8:36).
